summary: L.M. Myles, writer, podcaster, and Dr. Who fan, joins Scott to discuss “The Visitor” (DS9 S4E3), which, despite the name, doesn’t offer much screentime for Nana Visitor. Old Jake, Young Jake, and an unstuck in time Ben Sisko make for an interesting trio in this episode. Things discussed include popping in on your favorite reclusive writer (they love it!), how Jake causes the death of Dax, and whether or not you’d want to serve on a ship captained by Nog.Next on Random Trek: DS9’s The Search Part 1 & 2.

title: "The Enemy Within" (TOS) with Frank Wu
summary: Frank Wu, Hugo award winning artist, joins Scott to discuss "The Enemy Within" (TOS S1E4). Transporter malfunctions, freezing Sulus, dogs in costumes, and the monster that is inside all of us are all in this episode. Scott and Frank talk about the lyrics to the TOS theme song, what makes us us, the lack of empathy towards Yeoman Rand, and no one thought to take a parka down to an ice planet.Next on Random Trek: The Visitor (DS9).

title: "Lessons" (TNG) with Kara Scott
summary: Kara Scott, poker player and reporter, joins Scott to discuss “Lessons” (TNG S6E19). Awkward kissing, poor Picard wardrobe choices, and a roll out keyboard - This episode has it all. Kara and Scott discuss all manner of things including what it is like to date a Capt. Kirk, mature relationships, and how Capt. Picard makes us a little gooey inside.Next on Random Trek: The Enemy Within (TOS).

title: "Death Wish" (VOY) with Merlin Mann
summary: Merlin Mann, writer, podcaster, Internet nuisance, joins Scott to discuss  Death Wish ( VOY S2E18). This episode proves that the only thing better than one Q is double the Q. Scott and Merlin also discuss timescales when you’re immortal, and if this episode is a good choice for watching with your young daughter.Next on Random Trek: TNG’s Lessons.

title: "Inside Man" (VOY) with Clint Ecker
summary: Clint Ecker, programmer and snazzy dresser, joins Scott to talk about “Inside Man” (VOY S7E06). This episode features Reg Barclay, a Random Trek favorite, and Troi. Who doesn’t like Troi? It also has a bonus Reg, creepy stalker behavior, and a great deal of space swimwear.(Next week on Random Trek: Voyager’s Death Wish.)

title: "Shakaar" (DS9) with Derek Powazek
summary: Derek Powazek, web developer turned farmer, joins Scott to discuss Deep Space Nine’s “Shakaar” (S3E24). Nothing says a Bajoran DS9 episode like the intersection of religion, internal politics, and agriculture. What do soil reclamators look like? We don’t know and we don’t care. Topics discussed include why we should like the Bajorans more (but we totally like the Cardassians better), dirt farmer, and what does a freedom figher do after they’ve won their freedom.The novel Derek mentions is A Stitch in TimeNext on Random Trek: “Inside Man” (VOY).

title: "The Gift" (VOY) with Georgia Dow
summary: Georgia Dow, psychotherapist, senior editor at iMore, and host of Isometric, joins Scott to discuss Voyager’s “The Gift” (S4E2). Shed a tear because this is Kes’ last episode (though why didn’t she take Neelix with her?). This also happens to be the first appearance of the deborgified 7 of 9 in her striking uniform (note the corset, people). Topics include: Georgia’s least favorite TNG character, Scott’s reaction to said least favorite character, one sided pancakes, and why the mention of either lucid dreaming or guided mediation is a warning that you might be watching a bad episode of Star Trek.

title: "The Devil in the Dark" with Collin Donnell
summary: Collin Donnell, developer, twitterer, and brank hacker joins Scott to discuss one of the most iconic TOS episodes: The Devil in the Dark (S1E26). Door opening procedures, appropriate miner garb, Phaser 1 and Phaser 2, and basic mining colony administration tips are all discussed. Plus, the devil isn’t who you think it is (or is it? It isn’t).

title: "Equilibrium" with Antony Johnston
summary: Antony Johnston, writer for comics, graphic novels, and videogames in addition to the host of Unjustly Maligned, joins Scott to discuss DS9’s Equilibrium (S3E4). Trills, symbiotes, potential underground serial killers, and dodgy doctors are all discussed.

title: "The Squire of Gothos" with Steven Schapansky
summary: Steven Schapansky, of Radio Free Skaro and the newly launched Lazy Dr. Who, joins Scott to chat about the TOS classic: “The Squire of Gothos” (TOS S1E17)). They discuss the crazy amount of paperwork Starfleet requires, the power of mirrors, and the differences between early Dr. Who and early Star Trek.

title: "Workforce Part I & II" (VOY) with Joe Rosensteel
summary: Joe Rosensteel (that’s Joe Steel to you, kid), podcaster, infrequent Incomparable panelist, and Star Trek fan, joins Scott to discuss Random Trek’s first two part episode: Workforce Part I and Workforce II (VOY S7E16 and 17). Topics include if this should have been a two parter, factory automation, planet-wide shields, and Ralph Malph. These Are The Voyages (Volume 1) by Marc Cushman is also discussed briefly (and you should read it!).

title: "The Catwalk" (ENT) with Katie Floyd
summary: Katie Floyd, a Mac Power User, joins Scott to discuss “The Catwalk” (ENT S2E12). Topics include visceral reactions to the very existence of Enterprise (and the reboot movies), how great the Star Trek novels are, Porthos as the strongest character, water polo and iPad usage in the future.

title: "A Time to Stand" (DS9) with David Sparks
summary: David Sparks, better known as Mac Sparky, joins Scott to discuss “A Time To Stand” (DS9 S6E1). David admits that he is a Star Wars fan (shocking!), we compliment Julian Bashir, have questions about the final resolution of the episode, and talk about how without TNG David might not have gotten through law school (he’s a lawyer, you should hire him!).

title: "Loud As A Whisper" (TNG) with Myke Cole
summary: Myke Cole, writer and Capt. America fan, joins Scott to talk about Loud As A Whisper (TNG S2E5).We discuss how accurate the depiction of the military is on TNG, why it is ok that Wesley is driving the Enterprise, the state of lighting on Solais V, and use the phrase “lust warrior” fairly often. We also talk about how this episode has so many good themes, and yet still comes off a little bit on the wrong foot. Also, Riva’s hair.

title: "The Ensigns of Command" (TNG) with Annalee Flower Horne
summary: Annalee Flower Horne, science fiction writer and web developer, joins Scott to talk about The Ensigns of Command (TNG S3E2).We discuss how impossible the impossible is, how many showers Riker takes during a typical TNG episode, and the very important lesson Data learns about kissing.

title: "Identity Crisis" (TNG) with Victor Agreda Jr
summary: Victor Agreda Jr., Angry Dad Gamer and the man behind the Bakers Dozen Rules, joins Scott to discuss “Identity Crisis” (TNG S4E18). Topics include Geordi’s love live, how effects from the 90’s hold up to the HD treatment, and the impacts of Google Glass on the Federation.

title: "Clues" (TNG) with Carrie Anne Castillo
summary: Carrie Ann Castillo, the woman behind The Little Big Blog joins Scott to discuss “Clues” (TNG S4E14). There’s a mystery afoot. How do we know this? Well, the episode is called “Clues” and Capt. Picard keeps reminding us that there’s a mystery to solve. Data is acting oddly, Troi gets possessed, and the growth rate of moss is a super important plot point. What more can you ask from an episode of Star Trek?

title: Remembering Leonard Nimoy
guest: Jason Snell;Glenn Fleishman;Matt Gemmell;Steve Lutz;Nicole Wakelin;Jean MacDonald;Dave Caolo;Gedeon Maheux
summary: Leonard Nimoy, Spock, died on Feb. 27th. On this special episode of Random Trek Scott is joined by a number of past guests who share their thoughts about Spock and their favorite Spock moment.Scott's guests are:If you liked this episode you should check out The Incomparable 236: "Lived Long and Prospered."

title: "Blood Oath" (DS9) with Nicole Wakelin
summary: Nicole Wakelin, editor at GeekMom, Director of Automotive Content at She Buys Cars, and writer all over the place, joins Scott to discuss “Blood Oath” (DS9 S2E19). Who ordered the trio of Klingons? And what’s this about revenge? Star Trek board games are discussed, as is TOS actors reprising roles, and the right and wrong ways to ask someone if they’ve ever murdered someone.

title: "Oasis" (ENT) with Helene Wecker
summary: Helene Wecker, author of the fantastic “The Golem and the Jinni” joins Scott to discuss “Oasis” (ENT S1E20). What do you do when you’re stranded on an inhospitable planet? Create holographic friends and eat a lot of kumquats. And who is that in the back? Why, is that Odo? No, it is not.

title: "Judgement" (ENT) with Andy Ihnatko
summary: Andy Ihnatko, technology writer and podcaster, joins Scott to discuss “Judgement” (ENT S2E19). If you really enjoy Klingon courtrooms and Star Trek VI this episode of Enterprise is for you. Topics discussed include what kind of Star Trek fan Andy is, the problematic nature of Klingons, and lighting in Klingon mines.

title: "Shades of Gray" (TNG) with Casey Liss
summary: Casey Liss, of the Accidental Tech Podcast and Analog(ue), joins Scott to discuss “Shades of Gray” (TNG S2E22). Widely, and correctly, hailed as the worst episode of TNG ever this podcast covers everything from Starfleet Medical’s lax attitude towards quarantining people to the expensive nature of filming a TV show. Did I mention Shades of Gray is a clip show? In the second season of TNG? It isn’t good, people. Not at all.

title: "All Good Things..." (TNG) with Matt Gemmell
summary: Matt Gemmell, writer, joins Scott to talk about “All Good Things…” (TNG SE7E25). Random Trek’s first double length episode marks the final episode of “Star Trek: The Next Generation” ever, and possibility its best.Three different timelines, multiple shots of Picard in his jammies, and more cats than you can shake a positronic brain at can all be found in TNG’s finale. As well as some very touching character moments and a fine send off to the Enterprise crew.The twitter account Matt mentions is tng_s8 (for those of use who can’t accept that the 7th season was the final season).

title: "Waltz" (DS9) with Marisa McClellan
summary: Marisa McClellan, cookbook author and the writer behind the popular canning blog Food in Jars, joins Scott (to whom she is married) to discuss "Waltz" (DS9S6E11). Gul Dukat and Sisko are stranded on a remote planet. They eat some soup. They fiddle with a beacon. They argue a lot (sometimes with hallucinations). Dukat spirals completely into madness. A light hearted romp of an episode that will leave you asking: will he or won't he... kill all Bajorans.

title: "Evolution" (TNG) with Chip Sudderth
summary: Chip Sudderth, a host of the Audio Guide to Babylon 5 and host of the Two Minute Time Lord, joins Scott to talk about Evolution (TNG S3E1). Wesley is front and center in this episode and that isn’t as bad as you might think. Hungry, hungry nanobots, sabermetrics, and the proper collars for Star Fleet uniforms are discussed. You’ll also find out what costume Scott would dress up in if he had to cosplay at a Star Trek convention.

title: "Inheritance" (TNG) with Shannon Sudderth
summary: Shannon Sudderth, a host of the Audio Guide to Babylon 5 and frequent Two Minute Time Lord guest, joins Scott to talk about Inheritance (TNG S7E10). Topics include phasering to the candy center of a planet, the future of women in technology, and the realization that even androids can be embarrassed by their mom.

title: "The Chase" (TNG) with AnÅ¾e TomiÄ‡
summary: AnÅ¾e TomiÄ‡, podcaster and writer, joins Scott to talk about “The Chase” (TNG S6E10). This episode answers the question: why do all Star Trek aliens look a like? And the answer isn’t that great (turns out). We also discuss our favorite Trek movies, if this episode should have been a two parter, and why the Cardassians rock.

title: "Darmok" with Christina Warren
summary: Christina Warren, tech analyst, podcaster, and internet maven, joins Scott to talk about “Darmok” (TNG S5E2). Does this episode of TNG live up to the hype? Is Capt. Picard a their? And were did he get his Members Only jacket? All this plus Emoji on this Christmas episode of Random Trek.

title: "Initiations" (VOY) with Lisa Maria Martin
summary: Lisa Maria Martin, content strategist and information architect, joins Scott to discuss Initiations (VOY S2E2). This episode is one of those rare gems: a Chakotay centric story. Topics discussed include the deal with Neelix and what it is, Chakotay’s ambiguous tribal associates and fake rituals, and why the Kazon can build starships but can’t find water.

title: "The Measure of a Man" (TNG) with Brett Terpstra
summary: Brett Terpstra, a man of many projects, joins Scott to discuss The Measure of a Man (TNG S2E9).Such topics as the existence of souls, how to disarm (literally) an android, and how Riker evolves as a character are all touched upon.

title: "Pen Pals" (TNG) with Deborah Stanish
summary: Deborah Stanish, of the Verity Podcast (all about Dr. Who), joins Scott to discuss Pen Pals (TNG S2E15). They ponder the ramifications of the Prime Directive, the Riker School of Management vs. the Picard School of Management, wiping someone's memory without permission, and horse riding.

title: "The Mark of Gideon" (TOS) with Jean MacDonald
summary: Jean MacDonald, founder of App Camp for Girls, joins Scott to talk about “The Mark of Gideon” (TOS S3E17). Overpopulation, cranky Spock, the Gideon’s seeming complete lack of knowledge about how disease works, and the horrible life sucking powers of bureaucracy are all touched upon.Random Trek shirts are available for a few more days. You don’t want to be the only one at the Star Trek convention without one, do you?

title: "Who Watches The Watchers" (TNG) with Guy English
summary: Guy English, of Aged and Distilled and Debug, joins Scott to chat about "Who Watches The Watchers" (TNG S3E4). Religion vs. mythology, poor archery skills, Romulans, the ethics of creepily observing developing societies, and who loves the Prime Directive most are all covered during this episode.Don't miss your chance to buy a Random Trek Shirt, now available for a limited time.

title: "Babel" (DS9) with Jamelle Bouie
summary: Jamelle Bouie, staff writer at Slate, joins Scott to talk about Babel (DS9 S1E5). This episode features an aggrieved O’Brien, a poorly emoted Jake, and a goatee-less Sisko. Listen as we talk about why anyone would pay for replicated food, uncomfortable Ferengi characteristics, and how Voyager could have been good.

title: "Where No Man Has Gone Before" (TOS) with Katrina Griffiths
summary: Katrina Griffiths, of the Verity Podcast, joins Scott to discuss the second Star Trek TOS pilot: Where No Man Has Gone Before (TOS S1E1 or 3). 60’s contact lenses, Creepy Gary Mitchell transforming into Creepier Gary Mitchell, and the fate of Dr. Dehner are all covered.

title: "Rivals" (DS9) with Anthony Pascale
summary: Anthony Pascale, the man behind TrekMovie.com, joins Scott to talk about DS9's "Rivals" (S2E11). Topics include the finer points of space racquet ball, Prince Humperdinck, how pressing a button on an orb makes not a compelling casino game, and what Sisko does when he is alone in his office.

title: "Minefield" (ENT) with Matthew Yglesias
summary: Matthew Yglesias, executive editor of Vox, joins Scott to discuss Minefield (ENT, S2E4). Among the topics discussed include Matt’s crazy Trek lists, why no one on the Enterprise seems capable of doing anything, and what’s the deal with those crazy complicated mines anyway?

title: "Starship Mine" (TNG) with Jordan Cooper
summary: Jordan Cooper, host of the Tech Douchebags podcast, joins Scott to have some small talk about “Starship Mine” (TNG S6EP18). We discuss Capt. Picard’s fake horse-riding affinity, Tuvok’s shady past, why Geordi is the only hungry officer, and how to get out of attending a funeral when you’re a Starfleet Captain.If you enjoyed this episode you might enjoy the episode of Tech Douchebags I was on: The Book Hoarder.

title: "First Contact" (TNG) with Tony Sindelar
summary: Tony Sindelar, the Incomparable and co-DM of Total Party Kill, joins  Scott to discuss TNG’s First Contact (S4E15).Topics include Riker’s total lack of guile, Malcorian facial hair, the naming of planets, alien groupies, and when it is appropriate to beam somewhere.

title: "Sleeping Dogs" (ENT) with Lex Friedman
summary: Lex Friedman, famous for not having seen it, being Daily, Rebounding, and Turning a Car Around, joins Scott to talk about Sleeping Dogs (Enterprise S1E14). Scott expresses mild shock and then major regret after learning that this episode is the first Star Trek episode Lex has ever seen (spoiling: Sleeping Dogs is not a great first Star Trek experience). We determine that T’Pal is a Vulcan, Hoshi is better than the Universal Translator, and ponder just how badly it smelled on that Klingon ship.

title: "I, Mudd" (TOS) with Monty Ashley
summary: Monty Ashely, Incomparable panelist and Internet writer, joins Scott to talk about The Original Serie’s second Harry Mudd episode: I, Mudd (S2E12). Uniforms, the concept of computers (and if the Star Trek writers have any idea how they work), and Kirk taking the law in his own hands are all discussed.

title: "Indiscretion" (DS9) with John Siracusa
summary: John Siracusa, of ATP and Incomparable note, joins Scott to talk about DS9’s Indiscretion (S4E5). Scott explains the deal with Deep Space Nine, John questions the central premise, and some parallels to Star Wars are identified.The end of this episode features a Random Trek theme song written and performed by listener Adam Sakellarides. Thanks, Adam!

title: "Phage" (VOY) with David Loehr
summary: David J. Loehr, Incomparable panelist and playwright, joins Scott to discuss Voyager’s Phage (S1E5). Neelix’s lungs are stolen, and yet he still talks too much in this episode. Good old Harry Kim scans a wall, and the crew forgets the most important rule: never split the party.

title: "Remember Me" (TNG) with Jacqui Cheng
summary: Jacqui Cheng, Editor-in-chief of The Wirecutter, joins Scott to talk about TNG’s Remember Me (S4E5). In this episode who let Wesley fiddle with the Warp core and why, The Traveller as “Q Light,” and how Dr. Crusher definitely isn’t crazy (despite all the men thinking otherwise).

title: "Hope and Fear" (VOY) with Brianna Wu
summary: Brianna Wu, Head of Development at Giant Spacekat and one of the hosts of the Isometric Podcast, joins Scott to talk about Voyager’s Hope and Fear (S4E26). Bri explains why Voyager is the best Trek there is, we discuss Harry Kim and his love of bulkheads, and suggest some changes to Voyager’s lax security protocols.

title: "Timescape" (TNG) with Swoozy Clancey
summary: Swoozy Clancey is a nerdy nurse who has embarked on a journey of watching all of Star Trek: The Next Generation in order. Why not invite her onto Random Trek to talk about a random episode? Luckily for her, the fates were kind and picked a TNG episode: Timescape.Romulan and temporal anomalies, plus a dash of conference going make this an episode not to miss!

title: "Collective" (VOY) with Glenn Fleishman
summary: Glenn Fleishman, editor and publisher of The Magazine, host of The New Disruptors (which isn’t a podcast reviewing new Klingon and Romulan weaponry), and tweeter of 14 million tweets, joins Scott to talk about Voyager’s Collective (Spoiler: it features the Borg).This Voyager episode has it all: card playing, Borg babies, Harry Kim being totally lame, and 7 of 9 getting things done.

title: "Conspiracy" (TNG) with Michael T. Rose
summary: Michael T. Rose, of TUAW, joins Scott to discuss the first season The Next Generation episode Conspiracy.Put on your tin foil hat and watch out for Trapper Keepers. Aliens have infiltrated the highest ranks of Starfleet Command and Riker is pretty ok with it.Will Picard join the clean plate club? Can Starfleet survive? Is Data is the last man standing? Why are all the elderly Admirals wearing pajamas? All these questions, and more, are discussed in this episode.

title: "11:59" (VOY) with Ged Maheux
summary: Ged Maheux, of the Icon Factory and Gedblog, joins Scott to discuss Voyager’s “11:59”. Why does everyone in the Year 2000 drive cars from the 1970’s? Will they or won’t they? Do we care?Email everyone in a 100 mile radius because this episode of Voyager is perplexing.

title: "Errand of Mercy" (TOS) with Erika Ensign
summary: Erika Ensign, frequent Incomparable panelist and Hugo nominated (!) Verity Podcast member, classes up the joint with Scott to discuss the TOS episode Errand of Mercy).What’s the deal with the blue jumpsuited man Scott is obsessed with? How come every Klingon doesn’t get a sash? And is Captain Kirk a warrior, explorer, lover or all of the above?

title: "Looking for par'Mach in All the Wrong Places" (DS9) with Moisés Chiullán
topic: “Looking for par’Mach in All the Wrong Places”
summary: Moisés Chiullán, Founder/Host of ESN.fm, joins Scott to talk about the very first Deep Space Nine episode on Random Trek: Looking for par’Mach in All the Wrong Places.Quark loves a Klingon. Worf loves the same Klingon. Oh, and Kira is carrying Miles O’Brien’s baby. Add a few massages and inappropriate remarks from Dr. Bashir and you’ve got yourself an episode of Deep Space Nine.

title: "The Apple" (TOS) with Steve Lutz
summary: Steve Lutz, of The Incomparable, joins Scott to discuss The Original Series’ “The Apple.”Vaal loves us all, except Spock. Steve loves most of us but totally not Chekov.This episode features the Star Trek crew beaming onto paradise, but all is not as it seems.

title: "Reunion" (TNG) with John Moltz
summary: John Moltz, who has a Very Nice Website and co-hosts Turning This Car Around, joins Scott to discuss Random Trek's first Klingon heavy episode: TNG's Reunion.Grab a bat'leth, chill some Klingon bloodwine, and get ready to delve into the intricacies of the Klingon Empire's sometimes complicated rite of Succession (unless you use the EZ form). Also, Alexander makes his first appearance and anomalies are ignored. This episode has it all!

title: "Doctor's Orders" (ENT) with Greg Knauss
summary: Greg Knauss, he of the Incomparable, Romantimatic, and EOD, has the honor of being on the first Enterprise Random Trek episode: Doctor’s Orders.An awful theme song, a cute dog, a naked Denobulan, and a frustrated Vulcan? Sounds like a typical Enterprise episode.

title: "Waking Moments" (VOY) with Dave Caolo
summary: Dave Caolo, of TUAW, joins Scott McNulty to talk about Random Trek’s second Voyager episode: Waking Moments.Grab your skis and don’t fall sleep or the aliens will get you!

title: "Life Line" (VOY) with Serenity Caldwell
summary: Serenity Caldwell, of the Incomparable and roller derby note, brings with her the first episode of Voyager to grace Random Trek: Life Line (S6E24).Beam yourself across to galaxy and be ready to ponder the meaning of holographic animals, chocolate ice cream, and the scarcity of trained counselors in the 24th century.

title: "By Any Other Name" (TOS) with Dan Moren
summary: Dan Moren of The Incomparable and Not Playing fame joins Scott to talk about Random Trek’s first Original Series episode: By Any Other Name (S2E21).The Galactic Barrier will be breached as topics such as Kirk’s worthiness as a captain and the difficulty of acting as though you’re frozen are discussed.

title: "Tapestry" (TNG) with Jason Snell
summary: Jason Snell, The Incomparable host and Star Trek fan, joins Scott to talk about the TNG episode Tapestry (S6E15).Topics include Jason’s voyage to Star Trek fandom, to Q or not to Q, space casino games, the message of the episode, and much more.

title: Sleigh
summary: The difference between a slegh and a sled.

title: Charger follow-up
summary: Listener William challenges our ruling about chargers and we get deep into the weeds of car charging.

title: Hoodie
summary: Stephen Hackett has called us out and requests John’s ruling.

title: Blogs
summary: What’s a blog, and what’s a news outlet? Are Jason and John bloggers?

title: Spiders and Other Bugs
summary: Listener Kev needs us to unpack John’s comment about “spiders and other bugs.” Does that mean spiders are bugs? And what are the other bugs? Spooky!

title: Wire
summary: Listener Matt can’t stand it when someone calls a USB cable a wire. But what does John think?

title: Landscaper
summary: Who scapes the lands? Who gardens the gardens? Who mows and who blows? Not us!

title: Pasta Roundup
summary: John fields some important questions about pasta from listeners Connor, Joshua, and Lee, including the definition of Al Dente and noodles versus pasta.

title: Vehicle
summary: Listener Eric asks if vehicles are only motorized, and we ponder how small a thing can be before it’s not a vehicle anymore.

title: Glass
summary: Can a drinking glass be made out of plastic? Or is it just a cup?

title: Parasol
summary: Summer is in full swing, so Listener Ken has asked us to differentiate between umbrellas and parasols.

title: Market
summary: Listener Marc ponders the “VR headset market” and wants to know what makes a market a market.

title: Charger
summary: Listener Eric really needs his kids to differentiate between charger blocks and charging cables.

title: AI Hype
summary: Listener Christian, your time has come. Is an AI Lock the same as a Smart Lock? Or a Fuzzy Logic Lock? When bicycle gear shifters are called “AI”, how do we define what any of this means? I know—let’s ask John.

title: Spacesuits
summary: Listener Lorne asks what makes a spacesuit a spacesuit, and it gets complicated in a hurry.

title: 10th Anniversary Episode
summary: Let’s get back to basics. We celebrate our improbable 10th anniversary with a letter from Listener Scott, who has a lot of questions about his son’s book “Science Comics: Robots and Drones.”

title: Bay Leaf
summary: Listener Paul doubts the efficacy of the Bay Leaf. Host John ponders the longevity of Spices. Host Jason admits to keeping spices 15 years past their expiration dates.

title: Tech
summary: Listener Jason (not host Jason) wants to know if “non-tech items” are really tech items.

title: Unanchored Buoys
summary: Listener Ben asks: If a Buoy is unanchored and works hard to stay where it is, is it the Roomba of the seas?

title: Mushroombot
summary: Listener Jim wants John to weigh in on the story of the mushroom that was given a robot body, and while that does sound fascinating, the answer seems to be right there in the description.

title: Arc
summary: Listener Victor brings us a question from another “or Not?” podcast about how many points are required to make something a story, episode, or character arc.

title: Flying
summary: Listeners Joshua and Matthias want to know about flying in (or on) an airplane.

title: Gibson Robot Guitar
summary: Listener Jason (not that one) wants to know if the Gibson Robot Guitar is just trying to jump on the robot bandwagon as a form of fancy marketing.

title: Sandwich Legal Update II
summary: Two listeners have requested that we revisit recent court and podcast rulings regarding the definition of a sandwich. Also, Jason details his meager high-school lunch.

title: Roomba-like Items
summary: In the end, the Grain Weevils and robot lawn mowers come for us all.

title: Console
summary: Is a Game Boy a game console? What about a Switch? Can a handheld gaming device also be a console? What makes something a console?

title: Calendar Year
summary: Listener Alexander has seen through the calendar’s deceptions and wants to know why any old day couldn’t be the start of a new year. When does the year begin in our hearts?(Happy New Year, everyone!)

title: Tipping
summary: Listener Ben and his sister-in-law have come up with a sophisticated system of rules for when and when not to leave a gratuity. But someone else may have his own rules.

title: Sandwich Legal Update
summary: Many listeners are concerned about recent legal rulings that suggest tacos and burritos are sandwiches. But we all know who the real voice of authority is.

title: Fan/Light
summary: Listener Patrick is concerned about taxonomy, most particularly involving fans that are also lights.

title: Fast Food
summary: There are so many different ways to define fast food. Is pizza fast food? Also, Jason has a story about the Shake Shake in the Minneapolis airport.

title: Window
summary: I can see clearly now.

title: Henchman
summary: As so often happens with us, discussions of evil henchman end up becoming discussions of legal employment status.

title: Relay Podcastathon Special 2024
summary: Live from the Relay Podcastathon, Jason and special guest Casey Liss ask John a bunch of questions from the Robot Or Not question list.Topics include: All-In-One computers, dates, pasta, and antique vs. retro.It’s Childhood Cancer Awareness Month. Please consider donating as a part of our campaign at stjude.org/relay.

title: Catchphrase
summary: Oh, Listener Sean wants to know about catchphrases! Well, isn’t that special?

title: Homepods and Other Robots (or Not)
summary: In a rare timely episode, John and Jason discuss a report from Bloomberg’s Mark Gurman that Apple is designing a series of robots, including a “robot” that sits on a table and moves its display around, and a “robot” that follows you around your house folding laundry, reminding you of your mortality, and possibly running a viral campaign for Apple TV+ shows.

title: Double Space
summary: Listener Daniel would like John’s blessing for his practice of putting two spaces after every sentence he types.

title: Severe Weather
summary: Listener Arne received a severe weather alert for a fire. Fires are very bad, but are they weather? Are some natural disasters weather, and others not?

title: Tea
summary: Is “truffle mushroom tea” just a soup? Did a fancy New York restaurant play a trick on Listener David and his wife? And what is tea, really?

title: Hawaiian Shirts
summary: Are Hawaiian shirts just fun to wear, or are they cultural appropriation?

title: Airport Wheelchair
summary: Listener Erik sent us this video of self-navigating wheelchairs in the Miami Airport. Does the Roomba Rule apply?

title: Vending Machine
summary: Friend of the show Frank is seeking to delineate when something is a “vending machine” and when it’s just a machine that vends.

title: El Camino
summary: Thanks to Friend of the Show Casey, we’re talking about weird cars and car classes again.

title: Autonomous Excavator
summary: Listener Ivan sent in a link to an autonomous excavator that assembled a six-foot wall out of rocks. Is it the Roomba of construction materials?!

title: Dishwashing Methods
summary: A tale of dishwashers and large sinks.

title: Theme Songs / Skip Intro
summary: We follow up on some feedback about our theme songs, and theme songs in general, while taking on whether we use the Skip Intro button when we should be listening to TV theme songs.

title: ⚾️ Robot Umps ⚾️
summary: It’s baseball’s Opening Day, so here’s our discussion of automated balls and strikes, also known as “Robot Umps,” how they relate to automated Hawk-Eye tennis calls, and why we won’t ever know how good human umpires could actually be.

title: (Pizza) Pie
summary: Fresh out of the oven for Pi Day, here’s a discussion of who exactly thinks pizza is a pie.

title: Places You've Been
summary: Do you have to leave the airport or get out of the car to claim you’ve been somewhere? (And are you under oath?)

title: Killer Robot
summary: Listener Kent is building actual killer robots.

title: Hat
summary: What makes a hat a hat?

title: Streets
summary: I want to run, I want to hide, I want to tear down the walls that hold me inside. Sometimes the streets have no name, but other times they are named roads, or avenues, or boulevards, or drives. What does it all mean? Does Jason live on a road or a drive? When we go there, we go there with you. It’s all we can do.

title: Spatula
summary: Spatulas, scrapers, flippers, and home economics.

title: Coffee
summary: A question about cold brew coffee makes us question everything about coffee. Is everything coffee? Probably not.

title: Italian Ice
summary: A perfectly normal discussion of Italian Ice takes a left turn and goes into outer space, where other ices are available.

title: Musician
summary: When is someone a musician? Are DJs musicians? And more importantly, are John and Jason musicians?

title: Avoid All Robots
summary: Some timely news regarding a university warning its community members to “avoid all robots.”

title: Lies
summary: On John’s other podcast, Casey Liss often says he lied when he means he made a mistake. So what is a lie? (Trust us, we totally answer this one.)

title: Spoiler Policy
summary: Listener Nick wonders what John’s policy on spoilers is. (Spoilers for “Romeo and Juliet” and “Citizen Kane.”)

title: Nachos
summary: Hold on, John, Jason’s got this one.

title: Relay FM Podcastathon Special
summary: Live from the Relay FM Podcastathon, Jason and special guest Stephen Hackett ask John a bunch of questions from the Robot Or Not question list.Topics include: Toast, Roadkill, Sandwich Order of Operations, Garage, and Cereal Soup.Please donate to St. Jude and help move us one step closer to the day where no child dies from cancer.

title: Sigh
summary: Listener Jamie wonders whether his dog is really sighing. We discuss noises dogs make. Also, after posting our previous episode we realized we got the numbering of the podcast out of order. Sigh.

title: The Worst
summary: Listener Andrew is worried that things we say are “the worst” are really just bad.

title: Hiatus
summary: Listener Magnus is concerned that his favorite podcast is on hiatus. When is something on hiatus and when is it cancelled?

title: AI Camerabot
summary: Finally we talk about robots again. If a robot controls a camera, is it a camera robot?

title: Cookie Dough
summary: If it’s never meant to make a cookie, is it still cookie dough? (Also: Peanut Butter Spread, Cheese Food, and other food labeling we have known.)

title: Shade
summary: This time we’re throwing shade. But do sunglasses?

title: Keys
summary: If any device can open a door, is every device a key?

title: Buildings
summary: A chair is not a house and house is not a home, but is a house a building? And what about gazebos?

title: Dish v. Plate (revisited)
summary: Jason’s trip to his mother’s house makes him rethink his definition of what a dish is. Also, he gets some upsetting news about the long-term relationship between the fork and the spoon.

title: Ports
summary: Don’t anthromorphize ports. They hate that.

title: Beach
summary: Where do beaches exist? And what materials do they need to be comprised of?

title: Island
summary: The difference between islands and continents, and also why Pluto can be a planet if you want to lower your standards.

title: Stepmom
summary: Sometimes they’re wicked, sometimes not. Can an adult call a parent’s new wife a stepmom? Bonus: Can you be too old to be an orphan?

title: Ice
summary: Listener Chris clues us into an important ice safety campaign.

title: Shoes
summary: Shoes, socks, sandals, boots. Footwear is complicated.

title: University
summary: What makes a university? Is it the buildings, or the people, or the big hole you throw money into?

title: Friend of the Show
summary: Listener Rob and Listener Reiner, who are not Director Rob Reiner, want to know if they are Friends of the Show.

title: Happy New Year
summary: Are we too late to say it?

title: Roomba Update
summary: Some deeper questions about whether certain Roomba behavior makes it more or less of a robot.

title: Blaine the Mono
summary: Blaine is a pain, and that is the truth.

title: The Follow-Up Episode
summary: For the very first time, we do some housekeeping about holes, Russian robots, salad, genocide, Voltron, and available sales leads.

title: Garlic
summary: Is garlic a vegetable, an herb, a spice, or what?

title: Undead Zombie Spider Robots
summary: Spooky!

title: Werewolves
summary: If you’re a werewolf, are you a werewolf all the time?

title: House or Boat?
summary: It’s a house, but it floats.

title: Wheels and Doors
summary: Sometimes, everyone on the Internet wants John’s opinion.

title: A Group of Robots
summary: When robots flock together naturally, will humans give them a name? Or will we be too busy dying?

title: Voltron
summary: Many robots, one robot, or no robots?

title: Holes in a Straw
summary: Topology can be tricky.

title: Monolith
summary: It’s a big thing in the middle of nowhere. Does it need to be a rock to be a monolith?

title: Electronic vs. Electric
summary: When is something electronic, and when is it electric?

title: Cameos
summary: Is that just a really short acting part, or is it only a cameo?

title: Stay-at-Home Moms
summary: We salute all Moms, no matter their classification.

title: Robot Loathing
summary: Listener/Professor Lisa can handle conceptual analysis on her own, but she does wonder why campus delivery robots make her so angry. (It wasn’t just because they’re Russian.)

title: Pasta Draft
summary: A bunch of baseball writers drafted pastas. John has thoughts.

title: Magnetic Slime
summary: Does texture matter when it comes to robots?

title: Stillsuits
summary: Paul Atreides and the Fremen sure look cool, but won’t they die of hyperthermia in those suits?(Incomparable Members will find a special bonus episode of Robot or Not in the First Class feed today. Become a member for lots of goodies!)

title: CAPTCHAs of South African "robots"
summary: Select all ROBOT RELATED PODCASTS.If there are none, click Stop.

title: Accents
summary: John has one, but also doesn’t have one. Mary married some merry carrots.

title: Friendship
summary: Listener Ashley wants to know about the true meaning of friendship.

title: America
summary: Why do Americans crowd out the rest of two continents from the namespace? John thinks it’s about imperialism; Jason thinks it’s because our country has no proper name.

title: Semi-Homemade Cooking with John Siracusa
summary: Listener Scott wants to know what “homemade” cooking is. Jason made this episode from scratch. (But the theme song was store-bought.)

title: Email, and Preparing the Way (for Roombas)
summary: Jason starts to ask John a question, but everything gets derailed.

title: Car
summary: What makes a car a car, and not a truck, or an SUV, or a crossover?

title: Next Wednesday
summary: When is Next Wednesday? Is it Wednesday? Or the Wednesday after that?

title: Money
summary: What makes something money? Is gold money? Is Bitcoin?

title: Sundays
summary: Do Sundays start the week, or end it? When does the week end, and is that the weekend?

title: Cooking
summary: What’s cooking? Is making tea cooking? John’s answers may surprise you. They certainly surprised Jason.

title: Popcorn
summary: The proper way to eat popcorn. ðŸ¿

title: Camping
summary: Listeners Jono and Chris, and friend Tony Sindelar, have questions about what John defines as ‘camping.’ Suffering is surprisingly part of the calculation.

title: Photo
summary: Listener Beth seeks enlightenment about what makes something a photo.

title: Floating Bridge
summary: Listener Isaac wants us to judge if a certain “floating bridge” is actually a ferry. This leads, of course, to a discussion of infinite bridges and whether a fairy is a ferry in California.

title: Grocery Robot Swarm
summary: If robots at a grocery-store warehouse works in tandem, are they robots? If they have a hive mind, are they still robots?

title: A Criterion of Data
summary: Singular or plural?

title: Religious or Spiritual
summary: When you see an org chart and money changes hands, your spirituality has become something else.

title: Daylight Saving Time
summary: Should we really spring forward and fall back?

title: Dishwasher
summary: When do you run the dishwasher? Do you rinse the dishes first? And wouldn’t it be nice if our dishwashers were robots?

title: Rules for Watching TV
summary: Do you always start watching at the beginning? And do you have to watch till the end?

title: Burrito, Part 2 (Qdoba v. Panera)
summary: The strange case of the burrito sandwich.

title: Dog-Shaped Dogs
summary: What is the shape of a dog?

title: Self-Driving Cars, Part 2
summary: Tim Cook thinks that self-driving cars are robots. Does John want to revisit his opinion?

title: Pandemic Changes (or not)
summary: Has the pandemic made John reconsider some of his previous rulings? (One guess.)

title: Relish
summary: Not all pickles are pickles, and not all relish is pickle relish.

title: Pots and Pans
summary: What divides pots from pans?

title: Peanut Butter
summary: Chances are pretty good that the peanut butter you eat is terrible.

title: Bagel Update
summary: A very unfortunate bagel on either side of the Atlantic.

title: Books
summary: Is a book a bound, printed collection of pages, or is it something more?

title: Apocalypse
summary: On the occasion of the 100th anniversary of the robot, happy stuff: When does the apocalypse start, and when do we reach post-apocalyptic times?

title: Microscopic "Robots"
summary: We celebrate our 200th episode by going back to where it all started—news about whether something is a robot or not. Also, we may have inadvertently started a religion. (Congratulations, Listener Eric!)

title: Christmas Special
summary: In the spirit of the season, we discuss when a Christmas tree is dead. (Thanks to Listener Darran.)

title: Soda
summary: Fizzy water. Is it soda, or pop, or a soft drink, or something else?(Incomparable members also get a bonus episode about Coca-Cola and cocaine, also released today.)

title: Indoors
summary: When are we indoors and when are we outdoors? And where do tents fit in?

title: Video
summary: Is a GIF a video?(Incomparable members also get a bonus episode about movie studio logos, released today.)

title: Child
summary: When is a child no longer a child?

title: Henge
summary: When the definition escapes its antecedent.

title: Puppet
summary: When is it a puppet, and when is it just someone in a suit? And what does this mean for the future of Gritty?

title: Backup Brain
summary: If we clone your body and transfer your memories to it, is it you?

title: Game
summary: The universe is Candy Land.

title: Pillow
summary: You can use this podcast as a pillow, if you like, but it’s still not a pillow.

title: What We're Owed
summary: When a book series hasn’t completed, what does the author owe us?

title: Reboot
summary: Beginning in this episode, Chris Pine and Zachary Quinto will be portraying John and Jason. Or not.

title: The Cloud
summary: Is The Cloud just Other People’s Computers? Watch out for Cloud Men!

title: Gum
summary: Most people aren’t eating light bulbs.

title: Blanket
summary: Listener James sends us a special message from beneath his blanket.

title: Indie Developer
summary: What’s an Indie Developer, and is John one now? What does it mean to be “indie?”

title: Slots and Ports
summary: Is a port a slot? PCMCIA cards have slots, but USB devices have ports. Either way, Jason has to make amends.

title: Working From Home
summary: Whatever this is called, a lot of us are doing it these days.

title: Camera
summary: My other car is also a camera.

title: Tabs
summary: Tabs or spaces?AFTERSHOW: Commas.

title: Grocery Store
summary: But what if they also sell shampoo there?

title: Morning
summary: Morning has broken, like the first… morning?

title: Walking Distance
summary: It’s within walking distance. How far is that?

title: Swipe Right
summary: Where does your finger go when you “swipe right”?

title: Beard
summary: When is it stubble and when is it more?

title: Reading
summary: It’s fundamental, yes. But is it something you can do with your ears?

title: River
summary: When is a body of water a river?

title: Soup, Part II
summary: Is soup a drink? What separates liquids from food?

title: Dish
summary: From dish to plate to bowl.

title: City
summary: Does it all come down to the U.S. Postal Service?

title: Burgers
summary: And do sliders have to slide?

title: Augmented Reality
summary: An Accidental AR podcast.

title: Pet Names
summary: Can we differentiate between how people name pets and how they name children? Listeners Rover and Whiskers, drop us a line.

title: Smart Devices
summary: Where do we draw the line between a regular device and a “smart” device?

title: Leftovers
summary: When does a meal turn into leftovers?

title: Cover Version
summary: Listener Luke sent in this week’s theme song. Is it a cover version of our canonical theme song? When is a new version of a song not a cover?

title: Family
summary: What constitutes family? Blood relatives only? Are friends family? Are co-workers family? Can you escape your family?

title: Doors
summary: What about when they’re ajar?

title: Storefronts
summary: Select all the STOREFRONTS to prove that you’re a human.

title: Bacon
summary: By popular demand, John has done his research—or maybe not?—and is here to break down what is bacon and what is an impostor.

title: Campus Delivery Robots
summary: Prompted by a note from Listener Zach, we discuss the trend of “autonomous food delivery vehicles” on college campuses.

title: Pants
summary: The entire conversation is pants. (The Brits will get that.)

title: Board Games
summary: How much board is required?

title: Combination Restaurants
summary: We’ll see you at the Carl’s Jr./Green Burrito/KFC/Taco Bell.

title: TV and Movies
summary: When is it a TV show and when is it a movie? It’s confusing.

title: American Food
summary: It all goes back to Mesopotamia.

title: Live Action
summary: If the new “Lion King” film features CGI animals talking with other CGI animals, is it a “live-action” movie or just a different kind of animation? What about a movie like “Avengers: Infinity War”?

title: Milk
summary: Legal news: Is Almond Milk milk?

title: "Chick Flick"
summary: What is a “Chick Flick”? Let’s start off by taking apart the term itself.

title: Marty the Supermarket Robot
summary: In a rare topical episode, John and Jason discuss Marty, the tall, googly-eyed robot that may soon be roaming the aisles of a supermarket near you. Does Marty meet the Roomba test? Are the googly eyes fooling anyone?

title: Simulated Universe
summary: Is this real or are we in a video game? How can we tell the true nature of the universe?

title: Hacker
summary: Do hackers do good, or bad, or both?

title: Cult
summary: “Hokey religions and ancient weapons are no match for a good blaster at your side, kid.”Merry Christmas, everybody!

title: GIF
summary: Choosy mothers pronounce it differently.

title: Database
summary: Where spreadsheets and databases collide.

title: Soup
summary: “You haven’t done soup yet, have you?”

title: Phones
summary: Smartphones, dumb phones, feature phones, and computers in your pocket.

title: Toasters
summary: Slot toasters, toaster ovens, and the definitions thereof.

title: Podcasting
summary: What makes something a podcast? OMG, are we one?!

title: Bread
summary: Bread is bread, but what about hot dog buns, bagels, tortillas, and pitas?

title: Planets, and also Pluto
summary: John is given the opportunity to endorse or reject the rulings of the International Astronomical Union.

title: Job Security
summary: John’s worked (and left) a lot of jobs. What’s his personal philosophy about job security versus going it alone as an independent?

title: Nerds and Geeks
summary: The subtle and vexing difference between a nerd and a geek.

title: Programming
summary: What is computer programming? And what doesn’t qualify?

title: Reality TV
summary: When is a game show a game show, and when is it reality television? Also, we reveal our favorite reality TV show.

title: Personal Computers
summary: Is a Mac a PC? Is an iPad a computer? Does John favor a broad definition or a narrow one?

title: Gnocchi
summary: What makes pasta pasta?

title: Seasons
summary: The conundrum of seasons versus eternally pleasant weather.

title: Savory Donuts
summary: Bagels are not donuts, people.

title: Sweaters
summary: Listener Ed, we’ve got bad news.

title: Pets
summary: What makes an animal a pet?

title: The Midwest
summary: Did both of Jason’s parents both come from the Midwest, or only one? What are the true boundaries of America’s heartland?

title: Potato Chips
summary: From Sour Cream & Onion to BBQ, what are the “real” potato chip flavors?

title: Vacation
summary: If you don’t go anywhere, is it a vacation? What if you go somewhere, but you don’t relax?

title: Cheesecake
summary: Is cheesecake cheese, cake, pie, tart, or none of the above? Does the angle of the pan matter? Does crust content matter? Do any of us matter, really?

title: The Trolley Problem
summary: As recently highlighted on “The Good Place”, it’s a classic ethical conundum that John wants absolutely no part of. And what if the trolley drives itself?

title: Janet from "The Good Place"
summary: Never believe what a robot tells you.

title: Night (bark) Joggers (bark)
summary: A dog interlude.

title: Holidays and Holiday Movies
summary: What makes a movie a holiday movie? How do they celebrate winter holidays in warm climates? Merry Christmas to all, especially in Australia!

title: Death
summary: Okay, time to call it. Time of death— wait, wait, everybody hold on. How do we define death?

title: Life
summary: How can we call something alive?

title: Ice Cream
topic: There’s only one R in Sherbet
summary: It would seem like ice cream versus frozen yogurt would be the main debate. But the pronunciation of a third competitor completely derails us.

title: Brunch
summary: We discuss the names of meals and when they happen, and make an interesting(?) digression into human sleep cycles.

title: Salad
summary: From leafy greens to sugary Jell-O concoctions, all sorts of things are called salads.

title: Barbecue
summary: Continuing our confused series of episodes about food-related topics, it’s time for John and Jason to talk about Jason’s favorite food style and what happens when you put food on a grill.

title: Smoothie
summary: If everything can be a smoothie, then nothing is. So we try to define what makes a smoothie and acts as a bulwark against the milkshake.

title: Art
summary: I don’t know what it is, but I know it when I see it.

title: Donuts
topic: Two blind men describe an elephant.
summary: We don’t know quite what an old-fashioned donut is, but we know what we like… and what we don’t.

title: Artificial Intelligence
topic: When is a machine truly intelligent?
summary: What makes machine intelligence “real AI”? And what is the difference between strong and weak AI?

title: Anime and Kaiju
summary: The very definition of video entertainment from Japan.

title: Sport
topic: Baseball? Is not sport, is game.
summary: What makes something a sport, and not an exercise or a game?

title: Condiments and Favorite Foods
summary: Exploring Jason’s favorite food, what a “favorite food” even is, and the hazy dividing line between condiments and other edibles.

title: Science Fiction
summary: What’s science fiction? And more importantly, is Star Wars science fiction, fantasy, or something else?

title: Computer Chips
summary: Is everything a computer chip? Is nothing a computer chip? Jason thinks this is gonna be good. John thinks it’s obvious.

title: Canonical Bagel Flavors
summary: What is the canon of bagels? Why are some ingredients allowed in an Everything Bagel but not any other bagel style? What makes raisins an acceptable ingredient, yet bars blueberries? Mr. Siracusa, native of the great state of New York, educates Mr. Snell, one of those California hippie types, about what a real bagel is.

title: Pizza Toppings
summary: What toppings are allowed on pizza? And what about using a knife and fork to eat pizza? There are many rules.

title: Pizza
summary: John weighs in on what makes something a pizza, including the horror of the Turkey Dinner Pizza.

title: Sandwiches
summary: Exploring what makes a sandwich, while also discussing  the history of food, sandwiches as satire, and the difference between llamas and camels.

title: Supervillains
summary: John helps Jason figure out the precise moment when a villain becomes a supervillain.

title: The Robot
summary: Your hosts return to where it all began and then prepare to set out for new horizons. (Robot or Not will return in two weeks with a new series of episodes.)

title: Your Hosts
topic: John Siracusa and Jason Snell themselves.
summary: Are John and Jason robots? All will be revealed!

title: Human Beings
summary: Could it be? Are we all robots?

title: Captchas
summary: What does a robot do when it gets to a web page with a checkbox that says “I’m not a robot”?

title: The Gate at Jabba's Palace
summary: The gate at Jabba’s palace in “Return of the Jedi” talks to droids, or has something inside it that talks to droids. So is it a robot?

title: Autonomous Sailboats
summary: They roam the ocean, scanning for important data and relaying their information home. There are no humans on board. Are these lonely sea voyagers robots?

title: Shardik
topic: A monster from the Dark Tower
summary: The robotic guardian of the Beams. He looks like a bear but has a satellite dish on his head. He’s a thousand years old.

title: Nintendo R.O.B.
summary: Game controller, robot, or total embarrassment?

title: Pronunciation
summary: ˈrōˌbät or ˈrōbət?

title: Naked Robotic Core
summary: An unadorned iPhone can be a Naked Robotic Core, but is it a robot?

title: Mechagodzilla
summary: Look who was under the tree! It’s a giant mechanical monster!

title: Battlebots
summary: Among the fiercest creatures in the machine kingdom are the Battlebots. They’re designed for fighting! But are they really robots, or is that just a clever marketing name?

title: School Babies and CPR Dummies
summary: High school students carry them around and learn what it’s like to be a parent. Or you learn  how to revive them by pressing their chest and breathing into their mouths. But are these learning tools also educational robots?

title: K5 Mall Robot
summary: It patrols the mall. Sometimes it knocks over small children.

title: The Hosts of "Westworld"
summary: The HBO series “Westworld” makes us contemplate whether its central characters, the Hosts, are robots or not. (We recorded this episode after the first seven episodes of season one had aired; forgive us if it was revealed later that “To Serve Man” was actually a cookbook.)

title: The Bicentennial Man
topic: Robin Williams, Isaac Asimov, and Grobycs!
summary: A robot slowly turns himself human. When does he stop being a robot?

title: Metal Mario
topic: Do metal men dream of robot sheep?
summary: Sometimes Mario is metallic. Does that make him a robot?

title: Kayaks
summary: They are boats with paddles. What else are they?

title: The Borg
summary: Straight out of “Star Trek” come these technological villains. Also, we discuss larger issues including AIs and hive minds.

title: The Energizer Bunny
summary: It just keeps going, and going, and going….

title: Tachikoma and Fuchikoma
summary: Little cute robots from “Ghost in the Shell.”

title: SpaceX
summary: Self-guided rockets and drone barges.

title: Hot Dogs
summary: They’re sure tasty, and it’s meat between bread, but are hot dogs sandwiches?

title: Daft Punk
summary: They sure look like robots. But who’s under the masks?

title: Animals in "Blade Runner"
topic: How do you like our owl?
summary: The owl and the snake from “Blade Runner” raise some interesting questions.

title: Bubo
summary: A little metal owl from “Clash of the Titans.” Crafted by the gods, can he possibly be a robot?

title: Gort
summary: The robot from “The Day the Earth Stood Still”, plus a long digression into Star Trek androids.

title: Cartoons
summary: Is all animation “cartoons”?

title: Robots from "Castle in the Sky" and "The Iron Giant"
summary: Two beloved metal creatures from animation.

title: RoboCop
summary: That “Robo” prefix is sure interesting, and he’s probably a cop, but…

title: The Robots of "Futurama"
summary: Bender, Calculon, and Hedonismbot.

title: Tron
summary: He fights for the users inside a computer. Can software people be robots?

title: Canadarm
summary: A fancy “robot arm” from Canada. But when is a robot arm just an arm, and when is it a robot?

title: Silicone Stingray
summary: Part animal, part machine. But is it a robot?

title: Traffic lights in South Africa
summary: Please obey robot.

title: Serena Williams
summary: It’s Wimbledon time, and so our discussion turns to tennis, and Serena Williams—who is not a robot, despite her perhaps wishing she was.

title: Rossum's Universal Robots
summary: Karel Capek’s play that made this podcast possible.

title: Animatronic Creatures
summary: The Country Bears, Chuck E. Cheese, and the things from Five Nights at Freddy’s.

title: Filesystems and Flowerpot Robots
summary: Live from RelayCon WWDC 2016, it’s a special live edition of Robot or Not.

title: General Grievous
summary: He’s a droid with a cough. So what’s the deal?

title: Elevators
summary: They go up, they go down. They might even go sideways from time to time. And they can be smart. But are they robots?

title: Inspector Gadget
topic: What if penny met a dinosaur?
summary: Go go Gadget! Also we get off on a tangent about Penny, inspired by The Flop House.

title: The Doctor from "Star Trek: Voyager"
summary: Please state the nature of the medical emergency. Can a hologram be a robot?

title: Synths
summary: From the AMC TV series “Humans,” the lifelike Synths look like humans but don’t act like it. And they bleed a funny color.

title: Baymax
summary: He’s an inflatable, medical robot from “Big Hero 6”—but can you back up your personality and still be a robot?

title: The Incomparable's Logo
summary: Our own robot (or not) is in the spotlight at last.

title: The Tin Woodman
topic: You know, from “The Wizard of Oz”
summary: If he only had a heart.

title: T-1000
summary: It’s made of liquid metal.

title: Tamagotchi
summary: Is it even a game? What if you had a video game that featured a robot?

title: The Robots of "Destiny"
summary: From Bungie’s bestselling video game, Ghosts, Exos, Rasputin, and other things that might be robots.

title: Lego Simulated Worm Toy
summary: A software model of a flatworm, piloting a Lego Mindstorms toy.

title: The Matrix
summary: Agents and Oracles and Architects from the “Matrix” trilogy.

title: Chatbots
topic: In IRC, on AOL, and elsewhere
summary: They listen to us and talk back. But is that enough?

title: Replicants
summary: Roy Batty, Pris, and all the rest. They’ve seen the Tannhauser Gate, but are they robots?

title: Thomas and Friends
summary: Living rail cars in Sodor.

title: Crow T. Robot and Tom Servo
summary: The bots from “Mystery Science Theater 3000.”

title: Nanobots
summary: Enter the realm of the very, very tiny as John and Jason ponder if size matters when it comes to whether something is a robot or not.

title: The Internet of Things
summary: Security expert Bruce Schneier said the Internet of Things was a robot, but what does John think? You can probably guess.

title: Daleks and Cybermen
summary: Two enemies wrapped in metal shells from “Doctor Who” face their ultimate foe—the judgment of John Siracusa.

title: Prince Robot IV
summary: It’s right there in the name of this character from the acclaimed comic book “Saga,” but as we’ve learned, names can be misleading.

title: Burritos
summary: This one seems to have gotten in by mistake.

title: Swimming Pool Cleaners
summary: Things that clean your swimming pool: are they Roombas or just dumb hoses? Also, if a toaster can’t be a robot, can a robot be a toaster?

title: Cars (from "Cars")
topic: So who made the cars? And where are they?
summary: If the cars in Pixar’s “Cars” movies aren’t cars, what are they, and where did they come from?

title: Podcasts
topic: Are you listening to a robot?
summary: Just in time for the holidays, some existential questions. Also, could a robot be on a podcast?

title: Clockwork Droids
summary: Doctor Who’s clockwork repair droids (from the episodes “Girl in the Fireplace” and “Deep Breath”) come under scrutiny. Sure, they start out as robots, but do they become something else..?

title: Iron Man, Ultron, and Vision
summary: From the Marvel Cinematic Universe, and specifically “Iron Man 3” and “Avengers: Age of Ultron,” deep robot-or-not questions about Iron Man’s suits, Ultron, and the Vision.

title: Herbie The Love Bug
summary: A Volkswagen Beetle with a mind of his own!

title: Aperture Science
summary: GlaDOS, Wheatley, turrets, cubes, spheres and more.

title: Vicki from "Small Wonder"
summary:
She’s a small wonder, pretty and bright with soft curls. 
She’s a small wonder, a girl unlike other girls. 
She’s a miracle, and I grant you 
She’ll enchant you at her sight. 
She’s a small wonder, and she’ll make your heart take flight.   She’s fantastic, made of plastic. 
Microchips here and there. 
She’s a small wonder, brings love and laughter everywhere.

title: Lobot
summary: Cloud City’s majordomo from “The Empire Strikes Back” is in the spotlight.

title: robots.txt
summary: It’s right there in the name, but what about the things that connect to it? And what about when Merlin talks about putting things “in the robot”? We need answers, John!

title: Twiki and Dr. Theopolis
summary: We take you back to the days of “Buck Rogers in the 25th Century” to debate the show’s two artificial sidekicks.

title: Johnny 5
summary: That little guy from “Short Circuit.”

title: The TARDIS
summary: The blue box from “Doctor Who” might be sentient, might be alive, but is it a robot?

title: V'ger
summary: V’ger and the Ilia probe, both from “Star Trek: The Motion Picture”. Also, John complains about fake skin on androids.

title: Cylons
summary: The metal robots (and their fleshy successors) from the old and new “Battlestar Galactica.”

title: Home Appliances
summary: What would a toaster have to do in order to be a robot? This episode introduces Siracusa’s Law, which somehow involves kitchen countertops.

title: Sasquatch
summary: The bigfoot/sasquatch from “The Six Million Dollar Man.”

title: Space Probes
summary: From golf carts on Mars to New Horizons flying past Pluto, these are impressive machines, but are they robots?

title: Hitchbot
summary: He tried to hitch his way across the country, but was dismembered in Philadelphia.Image by archier on Flickr.

title: Droids
topic: The ethics of Star Wars sentience
summary: Are droids robots? Do they have rights? Is the Empire based on a robo-slave economy?

title: Pinocchio
summary: Are we seriously talking about magic here?

title: Marvin the Paranoid Android
topic: Life… don’t talk to me about life
summary: Your plastic pal who’s fun to be with!

title: Commander Data
summary: Is an android a robot?

title: The Terminator
summary: I know now why you humans cry.

title: Siri
summary: So-called intelligent agents.

title: The Major
summary: From “Ghost in the Shell,” a human brain in a mechanical body. And what about uploaded brains and bodies?

title: Jaegers
topic: Big robots with little people inside
summary: Big robots with people inside, as seen in “Shogun Warriors” and “Pacific Rim.”

title: Transformers
summary: Like the song says.

title: USS Enterprise
summary: The main computer of the USS Enterprise.

title: KITT
summary: The “Knight Rider” car is cool, but is it a robot? What about KITT’s evil twin, KARR? Also, the dark pre-history of Pixar’s “Cars.”

title: ASIMO
summary: Honda’s ASIMO, Sony’s AIBO, and other cute things that can do The Robot dance. Also, our Radio Shack memories.

title: Assembly-Line Robots
summary: Look for the union label.

title: Roomba
topic: The lowest possible form of robot?
summary: Does a self-guided vacuum cleaner cross John’s minimum bar for a robot? And what does that have to do with ants and dogs?

title: Telepresence Robots
summary: They’re funny, but are they robots?

title: Self-Driving Cars
summary: Pondering sentient Google cars, Johnny Cab, and autopilots.

title: Emotions
summary: The greatest prog rock album ever made.

title: K-9
summary: John and Jason try to understand robot dogs. Plus, a trip through old “Doctor Who” episodes.

title: Darth Vader
summary: Cyborgs and robots and humans—how do we tell these things apart?

title: Service Kiosks
summary: John’s position on supermarket self-checkout machines, Jason’s need for beer when he visits his in-laws, and whether attaching arms to things makes them robots.

title: Mr. Roboto
summary: We explain why we’re here, and then discuss the protagonist of Styx’s 1983 album “Kilroy Was Here.”

title: Origin
summary: A flashback to past podcasts, as a way of explaining why this podcast exists.

title: I am the Cheese
summary: Hope you’re not lactose intolerant! Matt Skuta returns to discuss John Cormier’s I am the Cheese (1977).

title: Christmas Special: "A Christmas Turkey"
summary: What, the one as big as me? Marina McCoy makes her holiday return to discuss Mário de Andrade’s sweet-and-salty “A Christmas Turkey” (1956).

title: The Watch House
summary: Who watches the Watch House? Not us, the book is better. Ross Cleaver returns to discuss Robert Westall’s The Watch House (1977).

title: Thanksgiving Special: Protest Songs
summary: The answer, my friend…is not a lyric in the any of the songs the McCoy Brothers discuss. For this annual drunk Thanksgiving Special, Rob, Dan, and John talk about Where Have All the Flowers Gone?, One Tin Soldier, and Alice’s Restaurant.

title: Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are Dead
summary: Podcasts could happen to anyone. David Loehr discusses exits and entrances in Tom Stoppard’s Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are Dead (first performed 1966, published 1967).

title: The Last Unicorn
summary: Don’t it allways seem to go, you don’t know what unicorns you got til they’re gone. Kathy Campbell discusses Peter S. Beagle’s 1968 The Last Unicorn.

title: R.U.R.
summary: BEEP boop what is… love? Well, we don’t figure this out, but John Siracusa does return to Sophomore Lit to discuss Karel Čapek’s play R.U.R. (1920), the origin of the word “robot.”

title: The Pushcart War
summary: Brush up on the Large Object Theory of History. Shaenon K. Garrity returns to discuss Jean Merrill’s The Pushcart War (1964).

title: Walden, or Life in the Woods
summary: If you’re suffering from Quiet Desparation, why not listen to the not-so-quiet voices of Dan Daughhetee and me discussing Henrey David Thoreau’s Walden, or Life in the Woods (1854)?

title: Elizabeth Bishop Poems
summary: Somebody loves us all. Rosalynde Vas Dias discusses three poems by Elizabeth Bishop: “Sestina” (1956), “Filling Station” (1956), and “Crusoe in England” (1971).

title: The Chrysalids
summary: Podcasts are the original voices in your head. David Dredrick discusses John Wyndham’s The Chrysalids (1955).

title: The Visit
summary: Make money fast with this one weird trick. Glenn Fleishman discusses Friedrich Dürrenmatt’s play The Visit (1956).

title: The Love Song of J. Alfred Prufrock
summary: And indeed there will be time to discuss this, the most mid-life white-guy crisis poem of all. Lisa Schmeiser discusses T.S. Eliot’s “The Love Song of J. Alfred Prufrock” (1915).

title: Frank O'Connor Stories
summary: I’ve heard it said by men of wide experience that podcasts used to be better in the old days. Kieran Healy discusses three short stories by Frank O’Connor: “First Confession,” “The Majesty of the Law,” and “Guests of the Nation.”

title: Emily Dickinson Poems
summary: Forever is composed of podcasts. Caroline Fulford discusses selected poems by Emily Dickinson (c. 1860-65).

title: The Best Christmas Pageant Ever
summary: Cigars are always trouble. Marina McCoy discusses Barbara Robinson’s The Best Christmas Pageant Ever (1972).

title: The Time of Your Life
summary: Sometimes you want to go where everybody is a thread in the fabric of the human condition. Also they know your name. Phil Gonzales discusses William Saroyan’s The Time of Your Life (1939).

title: Thanksgiving Special: Comfort Reads
summary: Hey, things are tough. The McCoy Bros, Rob, John, and Dan, discuss the books that get them through.

title: The Owl Service
summary: Ross Cleaver returns to talk owls, plates, and Welsh mythology in Alan Garner’s The Owl Service (1967).

title: The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy
summary: This episode has many omissions, and contains much that is apocryphal, or at least wildly inaccurate. Jacob Haller tries to make sense of Douglas Adams’s The Hitchhiker’s Guide to the Galaxy (1979).

title: Lysistrata
summary: What’s more cultivated and genteel than classical theater? David Loehr discusses Aristophanes’s Lysistrata (411 B.C.E.)

title: The Twenty-One Balloons
summary: Because twenty would be too few and twenty-two would be ridiculous. Shaenon K. Garrity discusses William PÃ¨ne du Bois’s The Twenty-One Balloons (1947).

title: The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time
summary: Rain Main meets Air Bud. Dan McCoy discusses stims and happy endings and Mark Haddon’s The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time (2003).

title: A Canticle for Leibowitz
summary: This is the way the world ends, not with a bang but with a bunch of monks sitting around copying stuff. Jelani Sims returns to discuss Walter M. Miller Jr.’s A Canticle for Leibowitz (1959).

title: Why I Live at the P.O.
summary: Stick some stamps on the top of our heads. Deborah Stanish discusses Eudora Welty’s “Why I Live at the P.O.” (1941)

title: The Phantom Tollbooth
summary: The most important reason for going from one place to another is to see what’s in between. Moisés Chiullán discusses Norton Juster’s The Phantom Tollbooth (1961).[We’ve re-issued this episode to correct an audio problem.]

title: A Perfect Day for Bananafish
summary: Podcasters: What Do They Know? Do They Know Things?? Let’s Find Out! Jason Snell talks about marine life in J.D. Salinger’s “A Perfect Day for Bananafish” (1948).

title: The Veldt
summary: Lions and tigers and bea— you know what, just lions. Jordan Morris is here to discuss Ray Bradbury’s story “the Veldt” (1950).

title: Heart of Darkness
summary: The Podcast! The Podcast! John Holt discusses the ill-fated cruise that is Joseph Conrad’s novelette Heart of Darkness (1899).

title: Tom Sawyer
summary: Though his mind is not for rent, it still is the subject of this episode. Jacob Haller discusses Mark Twain’s Tom Sawyer (1876).

title: Wide Sargasso Sea
summary: Actually, I need this sea in an extra wide. Caroline Fulford discusses postcolonialism and recurring fires in Jean Rhys’s Wide Sargasso Sea (1966).

title: The Burglar's Christmas
summary: The Burgermeister Meisterburger has nothing on this burglar! My wife Marina joins me for our annual Christmas episode. This time we discuss Willa Cather’s “The Burglar’s Christmas” (1896).

title: The Prince in Waiting
summary: The waiting is the hardest part. Ross Cleaver and James Randall discuss the apocalypse, palace intrigue, and the charm of 80’s BBC television in this episode about John Christopher’s The Prince in Waiting (1970).

title: Thanksgiving Special: Poor Richard's Almanack
summary: Fish and visitors stink in three days, but podcasts are evergreen! Dan and Rob return for the annual Thanksgiving nonsense with Benjamin Franklin’s Poor Richard’s Almanack (1732-1758).

title: Valley of the Dolls
summary: Raggedy Ann, Barbie, Chucky—they’re all here. That’s what this book is about, right? Erin Gambrill discusses Jacqueline Susann’s Valley of the Dolls (1966).

title: On the Beach
summary: Why just sit around waiting for the end of the world when you can hear a podcast about it? Jelani Sims discusses Nevil Shute’s On the Beach (1957).

title: History of the Peloponnesian War
summary: Kids today love Thucydides, right? Anyone? Daniel Daughhetee returns to discuss this late fifth century BCE chronicle of Athens v. Sparta.

title: James Thurber
summary: It’s a naive literary podcast without any breeding, but I think you’ll be amused by its presumption. Dan Cassino discusses James Thurber’s “The Catbird Seat” (1942) and The 13 Clocks (1950).

title: Through the Looking-Glass
summary: If you’ve believed six impossible things before breakfast, why not listen to this podcast before lunch? Phil Gonzales discusses Lewis Carroll’s Through the Looking-Glass, and What Alice Found There (1871).

title: The Grapes of Wrath
summary: After eight years of the podcast I finally do the inevitable. Shelly Brisbin discusses John Steinbeck’s The Grapes of Wrath (1939).

title: Howl's Moving Castle
summary: Howl likes to move it, move it. Audrey Lazaro and Dan McCoy are on to discuss Diana Wynne Jones’s book Howl’s Moving Castle (1986).

title: Long Day's Journey Into Night
summary: I don’t care how long this day’s journey has been, so help me I will turn this car around if you kids don’t stop. Kris Markel discusses Eugene O’Neill’s Long Day’s Journey Into Night(written 1941, published 1956).

title: The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie
summary: Jean, Jean, the roses are red and all of the leaves have gone green, so Glenn Fleishman and John are discussing Muriel Spark’s The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie (1961).

title: Carrie's War
summary: Ross Cleaver discusses Carrie’s War (what is it good for?), Nina Bawdwin’s 1973 children’s book about evacuations, skulls, and grumpy Welshmen.

title: The Snows of Kilimanjaro
summary: Grab a whisky and soda and put your leg up. My dad and I discuss Ernest Hemingway’s “The Snows of Kilimanjaro” (1936). Bonus content: a visit to the Hemingway Home in Key West!

title: Beloved
summary: Jelani Sims returns to discuss the literal and metaphorical ghosts of Toni Morrison’s Pulitzer Prize winning novel Beloved (1987).

title: Great Expectations
summary: I have good feelings about this one! Zach Powers returns to discuss desparate criminals and mysterious benefactors in Charles Dickens’s Great Expectations (1861).

title: A Christmas Carol
summary: There are many podcasts from which I might have derived good, by which I have not profited. John and Marina discuss Charles Dickens’s A Christmas Carol (1843).

title: Stuart Little
summary: This is one weird mouse book. Phil Gonzales and John discuss E. B. White’s Stuart Little(1945).

title: Thanksgiving Special: The Wreck of the Hesperus
summary: It’s Thanksgiving, so of course Rob, John, and Dan drink and discuss “The Wreck of the Hesperus” by Henry Wadsworth Longfellow (1842).

title: Macbeth
summary: Probably best not to listen to this episode while you’re in a theatre. Shannon Campe and John discuss Shakespeare’s Macbeth (1605-ish).

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray
summary: The podcasts that the world calls immoral are podcasts that show the world its own shame. Tamar Avishai and John discuss Oscar Wilde’s The Picture of Dorian Gray (1831).

title: The Canterbury Tales
summary: Those smale foweles maken melodye got nothin’ on us: Kathy Campbell and John discuss Chaucer’s The Canterbury Tales (c. 1400).

title: Beowulf
summary: The original Farewell to Arms. Nathan Alderman discusses Beowulf (c. 1000).

title: Epic of Gilgamesh
summary: Gilgamesh, a king, at Uruk. It’s not just a Star Trek meme. Gregory Fried talks ritual sex, heavenly bulls, and sneaky snakes in the Epic of Gilgamesh.

title: The Metamorphosis
summary: Gregor’s mother warned him about days like this. Jason Snell discusses Franz Kafka’s inescapable novella, The Metamorphosis (1915).

title: Bartleby, the Scrivener: A Tale of Wall Street
summary: Audrey Lazaro discusses Mellville’s 1853 story, “Bartleby the Scrivener,” one of the top three bits of scrivener fiction ever.

title: The Egypt Game
summary: No, I won’t make a Bangles joke. Erin Gambrill discusses Zilpha Keatley Snyder’s The Egypt Game (1967).

title: Bambi, a Life in the Woods
summary: Bambi’s not so cute in this gritty new reboot. Glenn Fleishman discusses Felix Salten’s 1923 parable about what goes on in the woods. Also we talk a lot about copyright.

title: At the Mountains of Madness
summary: Climb ev’ry mountain—except these mountains, they’re nuts. Phil Gonzales discusses H.P. Lovecraft’s “At the Mountains of Madness,” written in 1931 and published in 1936.

title: Under Milk Wood
summary: To begin at the beginning: David Loehr is back in the slow, black, crowblack, podcast-bobbing sea to discuss Dylan Thomas’s Under Milk Wood (1954).

title: The Bell Jar
summary: New Year’s is a time for optimism, but instead Christy Admiraal discusses Sylvia Plath’s 1963 roman Ã  clef, the Bell Jar. Also, John totally gets the dates wrong for this book’s complicated publishing history.

title: Christmas Special: Gift of the Magi
summary: But I sold my Zune to buy you this podcast! Marina and John discuss hair, watches, and O. Henry’s “The Gift of the Magi.”

title: Thanksgiving Special: Burma-Shave
summary: It’s turkey time / once again / Dan and Rob / dive right in / we discuss / Buma-Shave!

title: Three Men in a Boat (To Say Nothing of the Dog)
summary: Let your boat of life be light, packed with only what you need—a podcast, for example, where Bill O’Donnell discusses Jerome K. Jerome’s very silly Three Men in a Boat (1889).

title: Peter Pan
summary: Grab on to your happy thought and join Shannon Campe in discussing James Barrie’s complicated children’s novel Peter Pan (1911), originally called Peter and Wendy.

title: Spoon River Anthology
summary: Spoon River…wider than a mile. Okay, now that we have that out of our way, join Lisa Schmeiser as we discuss Edgar Lee Master’s poetic collection *Spoon River Anthology *(1915).

title: The Dispossessed
summary: Anarchy in the U. K. (LeGuin)! David Woken talks a lot of politics and a little story as we discuss The Dispossessed (1974).

title: Kerouac and Ginsberg
summary: Gena Radcliffe and John don’t blab any drab gab—they chatter hep patter about Jack Kerouac’s “October in the Railroad Earth” (1957) and Allen Ginsberg’s “Howl” (1954-55).

title: Flowers for Algernon
summary: I no I wil be smart won day. Until thin I will diskus Daniel Keyes’s epistolary novel Flowers for Algernon (1966) with Jason Snell.

title: Dracula
summary: Please invite in Jelani Lee and Matt Skuta to discuss Bram Stoker’s Dracula (1897). We can’t start until you do.

title: Hans Christian Andersen
summary: Let’s all hunker around this match and discuss some of the tales by Hans Christian Andersen. David Loehr returns.

title: George Orwell Essays
summary: It’s phraseology and pachyderms, as Daniel Daughetee discusses Orwell’s “Politics and the English Language” (1946) and “Shooting an Elephant” (1936).

title: Our Town
summary: Enjoy every, every minute of Phil and John discussing Thornton Wilder’s Our Town (1938).

title: Persuasion
summary: Maybe you should consider listening to this episode, in which Sammi C. discusses Jane Austen’s Persuasion (1817). Actually, we must insist.

title: Yes, Virginia, There is a Santa Claus
summary: Marina McCoy returns to discuss faith, fairies, and newspapers in Francis Pharcellus Church’s “Yes, Virginia, There is a Santa Claus” (1897).

title: The Crucible
summary: Why am I persecuted here? Travis Bedard discusses Arthur Miller’s 1953 The Crucible.

title: Trees
summary: I think that I will never see brothers so drunk as we three. Drunken Thanksgiving continues this year with Rob, Dan, and John discussing Joyce Kilmer’s Trees (1914).

title: Atlas Shrugged
